questions.text: How is Na+ absorbed in an empty intestine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the empty intestine (between meals), the absorption of Na+ occurs via Na+-H+ exchanger.

  • Between meals (fasting state):
    • Na+ is absorbed via Na+/H+ exchanger (passive transport).
    • Cl- is absorbed via the Cl-/HCO3- exchanger.
    • Water follows passively with Na+ and Cl- absorption.
  • In the small intestine (during digestion):
    • Na+ is absorbed along with glucose and amino acids via secondary active transport. (Option A)
    • Glucose absorption enhances Na+ reabsorption.
  • In the distal colon:
    • Na+ enters the apical membrane through ENaC (epithelial sodium channels), similar to the distal tubule in the kidneys. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following carbohydrate-digesting enzymes hydrolyse the α1:6 linkages in polysaccharides?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The oligosaccharides and other substrates are hydrolysed at α1:6 linkages by isomaltase secreted from the small intestine.

Salivary Amylase (Oral Cavity): (Option A)

  • Begins starch digestion.
  • Optimal activity at pH 6.7.
  • Hydrolyses internal α1:4 linkages, not α1:6 linkages.
  • Remains partially active in the stomach and small intestine.

Pancreatic Amylase (Small Intestine): (Option B)

  • Continues the digestion of starch.
  • Also hydrolyses internal α1:4 linkages, but not α1:6 linkages.

End Products of Amylase Activity:

  • Oligosaccharides, maltose, maltotriose, and α-limit dextrins.

Isomaltase (Small Intestine): (Option C)

  • Hydrolyses α1:6 linkages of oligosaccharides and dextrins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an endopeptidase?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase, while the elastases, trypsin, and chymotrypsin are endopeptidases.

Proteases:

  • Proteases are enzymes that digest proteins.
  • They are classified based on the site of cleavage in the amino acid chain:
    • Exopeptidases:
      • Cleave amino acids from the ends of the protein chain.
    • Endopeptidases:
      • Cleave peptide bonds within the middle of the protein chain.

Key Takeaway:

Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase that cleaves amino acids from the ends of peptide chains, whereas trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastase are endopeptidases that break peptide bonds within the protein chain.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy's parents took him to the paediatrician for a routine checkup. The paediatrician evaluated him and found that he had a congenital defect in the transport of neutral amino acids in the intestine. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The congenital disease associated with the transport of neutral amino acids is Hartnup disease.

  • In humans, Hartnup disease is caused by a congenital defect in the transport of neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules.
  • Cystinuria results from a congenital defect in the transport of basic amino acids.
  • Despite these transport defects, nutritional deficiencies of the affected amino acids are rare.
  • This is because the body compensates through peptide transport mechanisms.

Explanation of other options:

Lactose intolerance (Option B) occurs due to the absence of lactase enzymes. It is a congenital defect. Due to the inability to digest the lactose, it produces diarrhoea, bloating and pain in the abdomen. The simplest treatment is to avoid dairy products.

Celiac disease (Option C) is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten (a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye). It damages the small intestine lining by intestinal T cells, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.

Key Takeaways:

Hartnup disease is a congenital defect in the transport of neutral amino acids in the intestine and kidneys.

questions.text: True about short-chain fatty acids in the colon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA)are produced by colonic bacteria through the process of fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and other components of the dietary fibre.
  • SCFAs are absorbed by specific transporters present in colonic epithelial cells.
  • Uses of SCFA:
    • Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) are absorbed by the exchange of H+, partly contributing to acid-base balance in the wall of the colon.
    • SCFA also promotes Na+ absorption.
    • Absorbed SCFAs are metabolised and make a significant contribution to the total caloric intake. (Option B ruled out)
    • It has a trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells and also combats the inflammation. (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are formed by fermentation of dietary fibers by colonic bacteria, contribute significantly to caloric intake, and have a trophic and anti-inflammatory effect on colonic epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following transport proteins helps in the transport of iron out of the basolateral membrane into the interstitial fluid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • DMT1is an apical membrane iron transporter that transports iron in Fe++ (Option A)
  • DCYTBis Fe+ reductase, which converts Fe+3 to Fe+2.
  • HCP1is a heme transporter protein into the enterocyte.
  • Ferroportin 1is present at the basolateral membrane, which allows Fe+2 to enter the interstitial fluid from the (Option B)
  • Hephaestin(Heph), which converts Fe2+ to Fe3+. (Option C)
  • In plasma, Fe3+is transported bound to the iron transport protein transferrin (TF). (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Ferroportin 1 (FPN1) is an iron exporter located on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes that transports Fe2+ into the interstitial fluid.

questions.text: Absorption of which of the listed substances is Na+ independent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin B12 is a water-soluble vitamin absorbed in the ileum, and its absorption is Na+-independent. It requires intrinsic factor, a glycoprotein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, for absorption in the terminal ileum.

In contrast:

  • Vitamin C and most B vitamins (like B1, B6, niacin, pantothenate, and biotin) are absorbed in the upper small intestine via Na+-Na-dependent cotransporters. (Option B, C & D)
  • Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) are absorbed in the small intestine with the help of micelles formed with bile salts.

Key Takeaway:

  • Vitamin B12 and folate absorption are Na+- independent, while other water-soluble vitamins like B1, B6, and C use Na+- dependent transport, and fat-soluble vitamins are absorbed via micelles.

questions.text: Which of the following substance/s is/are involved in peristalsis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peristalsis involves coordinated action of acetylcholine and substance P (causing contraction behind the bolus) and nitric oxide and VIP (causing relaxation ahead), all contributing to forward propulsion of gut contents.

Peristalsis:

  • Peristalsis is the involuntary muscle contractions in the form of waves that move food, liquid, and other substances through the digestive tract.
  • Its function is to propel the food forward to the caudal region.
  • It is initiated by local stretch releases of serotonin, which activate sensory neurons that activate the myenteric plexus.
  • It occurs with the relaxation wave ahead of the bolus of food and the contraction wave behind the bolus, progressing towards the caudal region.
  • Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction activate neurons that secrete nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP), producing the relaxation ahead of the stimulus.
  • Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction in the plexus activate neurons that release substance P and acetylcholine, causing smooth muscle contraction behind the bolus

questions.text: Basal electrical rhythm (BER) is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal. BER is not seen in which segments of the GIT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal electrical rhythm (BER) is not present in the oesophagus and upper part of the stomach.

  • Spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in membrane potential between about −65 and −45 mV are known as basal electrical rhythm.
  • Basal electrical rhythm is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal.
    • Rate: 3-4 waves/min
    • Velocity: 1 to 3-4 cm/sec
  • The interstitial cells of Cajal are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features that send long, multiple-branched processes into the intestinal smooth muscle starting from the stomach.
  • In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus; in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. (Option B & C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase spikes and smooth muscle tension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Epinephrine inhibits gastrointestinal activity by reducing spike potentials and smooth muscle tension, unlike stretch, acetylcholine, and parasympathetic stimulation, which all enhance gut motility.

  • Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER) is the rhythmic oscillation of membrane potential in GI smooth muscle.
  • It does not initiate contraction on its own.
  • Spike potentials superimposed on BER are required to trigger smooth muscle contraction.
  • Stretch, acetylcholine, and parasympathetic stimulation all increase the number of spike potentials, thereby increasing smooth muscle tension and contraction. (Option A, B & C)
  • Epinephrine and sympathetic stimulation reduce spike potentials and thereby decrease smooth muscle tension and contraction.

Key Takeaway:

  • Epinephrine decreases GI smooth muscle activity, while stretch, acetylcholine, and parasympathetic stimulation all promote increased spikes and contraction.

choices.text: It occurs as the food enters the small intestine
During MMC activity, GI secretions decrease

questions.text: True about migrating motor complex (MMC)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The migrating motor complex is initiated by motilin.

Migrating Motor Complex (MMC):

  • MMC is a cyclical, peristaltic wave that sweeps from the oesophagus through the entire gastrointestinal tract.
  • It occurs during the interdigestive (fasting) period, not when food enters the small intestine.
  • MMC is initiated by the hormone motilin.
  • It serves as an "interdigestive housekeeper", clearing residual contents in the stomach and small intestine. (Option A & D)
  • MMC cycles occur approximately every 90-100 minutes.
  • The wave progresses at a rate of 3 contractions per minute.
  • GI secretions do not decrease during MMC; instead, motility increases to clear debris. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

  • Motilin initiates the migrating motor complex, which occurs during fasting to clear the GI tract in preparation for the next meal.

questions.text: Swallowing is triggered by which nerves?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Swallowing (deglutition) is a reflex involving sensory input from the trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves, which coordinate the complex motor activity via brainstem centres.

Swallowing (Deglutition):

  • Deglutition is the process of swallowing food.
  • It is a reflex response involving multiple cranial nerves.
  • Sensory impulses arise from the trigeminal (V), glossopharyngeal (IX), and vagus (X) nerves.
  • These impulses are triggered by stretch receptors around the pharyngeal opening and tonsillar pillars.
  • The signals are relayed to the nucleus of the tractus solitarius and nucleus ambiguus in the brainstem.
  • Efferent (motor) fibres reach the pharyngeal muscles and tongue via the trigeminal (V), facial (VII), and hypoglossal (XII) nerves.
  • The act of swallowing has:
    • A voluntary oral phase
    • Involuntary pharyngeal and oesophageal phases
  • Deglutition apnoea is the temporary cessation of breathing during swallowing.

Key Takeaway:

  • Swallowing is triggered by cranial nerves V, IX, and X, integrating sensory input to initiate a coordinated motor response.

choices.text: The tonic activity of the lower oesophageal sphincter
Flap valve mechanism of oblique muscle fibres of the stomach

questions.text: Which of the following factors prevents the regurgitation from the stomach?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stomach contents are highly acidic and must be prevented from refluxing into the oesophagus to avoid mucosal damage.
  • The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is an intrinsic sphincter that is tonically active and relaxes only during the deglutition reflex. (Option A)
  • An extrinsic sphincter is formed by the crural diaphragm (skeletal muscle fibres), which surrounds the oesophagus near the LES. (Option B)
  • Oblique (sling) fibres of the stomach wall act as a flap valve, aiding in closure of the esophagogastric junction, especially when intragastric pressure increases. (Option C)

choices.text: The Contraction of the pyloric sphincter is longer than the duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following does not prevent regurgitation from the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrin promotes pyloric sphincter relaxation and increases gastric motility, which can facilitate regurgitation from the duodenum if unopposed.

Prevention of Duodenogastric Regurgitation:

  • Regurgitation from the duodenum to the stomach must be prevented for proper digestion and coordination of gastric emptying.
  • Pyloric segment contraction tends to persist slightly longer than duodenal contraction, helping prevent backflow. (Option A)
  • Hormones that inhibit gastric emptying, thereby reducing the chance of regurgitation:
    • Cholecystokinin (CCK) (Option C)
    • Secretin (Option D)
    • Gastric Inhibitory Peptide (GIP)
  • These hormones inhibit pyloric relaxation, allowing more time for gastric digestion.
  • Gastrin, released by G-cells in response to food (especially protein), increases gastric motility and promotes relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
  • Other factors that inhibit pyloric sphincter contraction include:
    • Vagal nerve stimulation
    • Enterogastric reflex

Key Takeaway:

  • Gastrin relaxes the pyloric sphincter and enhances gastric motility, which may increase the risk of duodenogastric regurgitation.

choices.text: There is incompetence of the lower oesophagal sphincter
Incomplete relaxation of the sphincter on swallowing
It can be treated with H2 receptor blockers

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with difficulty swallowing and a feeling of food sticking in her chest. Following clinical evaluation, she is diagnosed with achalasia cardia. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Achalasia cardia is marked by failure of the lower oesophageal sphincter to relax properly during swallowing, along with absent or uncoordinated peristalsis in the esophagus.

Disorders of the Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES):

  • Achalasia Cardia:
    • Caused by inability of the LES to relax.
    • Associated with increased resting LES tone.
    • Characterized by incomplete relaxation during swallowing.
    • Treatment options:
      • Pneumatic dilation of the sphincter.
      • Surgical myotomy (incision of esophageal muscle).
  • Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD):
    • Caused by LES incompetence (failure to contract properly).
    • Presents with heartburn and esophagitis.
    • Medical management:
      • H2-receptor blockers or proton pump inhibitors to reduce acid secretion.
  • Surgical option:
    • Fundoplication to reinforce the LES.

Explanation of other options:

There is incompetence of the lower oesophageal sphincter (Option A): This describes gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not achalasia; achalasia involves a hypertonic LES that fails to relax, not an incompetent one.

Heartburn (Option C): Although some achalasia patients may report chest discomfort, heartburn is more typical of acid reflux (GERD), not a primary feature of achalasia.

It can be treated with H2 receptor blockers (Option D): H2 blockers reduce gastric acid secretion, used in GERD; achalasia treatment involves pneumatic dilation, nitrates, calcium channel blockers, or surgical myotomy, not acid suppression.

Key Takeaway:

  • Achalasia cardia is characterized by incomplete relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter during swallowing and impaired esophageal peristalsis.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for triggering the vomiting reflex at the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Serotonin (5-HT) plays a key role in initiating the vomiting reflex, particularly through 5-HT₃ receptors.
  • It is released by enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine in response to toxins, irritants, or chemotherapy.
  • These signals travel via the vagus nerve to the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the area postrema.
  • The CTZ contains both dopamine D₂ receptors and 5-HT₃ receptors involved in triggering emesis.
  • Antiemetic drugs work by blocking these receptors:
    • Ondansetron blocks 5-HT₃ receptors
    • Chlorpromazine and Haloperidol block D₂ receptors
  • Other neurotransmitters like GABA, epinephrine, and acetylcholine do not play a primary role in activating the CTZ. (Option A, B & C)

Key Takeaway:

Serotonin activates 5-HT₃ receptors in the CTZ, playing a crucial role in triggering the vomiting reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with gastric motility during the fed (post-meal) state?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The migrating motor complex (MMC) occurs during the fasting state, not after meals.

Based on Types of Gastric Motility:

  • Gastric motility in the fasting (empty) state includes:
    • Migrating Motor Complex (MMC): A strong peristaltic wave that occurs every 90 minutes, stimulated by motilin, to clear residual contents.
    • Hunger Contractions: Rhythmic peristaltic movements that begin in the stomach after several hours of fasting.
  • Gastric motility in the fed (post-meal) state includes:
    • Receptive Relaxation: The fundus and body of the stomach relax to accommodate incoming food.
    • Segmentation Contractions (Mixing): Help in churning and mixing the food with gastric secretions for digestion.
    • Gastric Emptying (Peristalsis): Coordinated contractions propel digested food toward the pylorus and duodenum.

Key Takeaway:

  • Migrating motor complex occurs in the fasting state, while receptive relaxation, segmentation contractions, and gastric emptying are part of fed-state gastric motility.

choices.text: Increased noradrenergic discharge from splanchnic nerves

questions.text: Which of the following factors can contribute to the development of paralytic ileus?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Paralytic (Adynamic) Ileus:

  • Paralytic ileus is a type of bowel obstruction where food or drink does not pass through the intestines due to a loss or inhibition of peristaltic movements.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Inhibition of small intestinal contractions leads to distension, forming irregular gas- or fluid-filled pockets.
    • Common after abdominal or pelvic trauma or surgery, which directly inhibits intestinal smooth muscle activity. (Option A)
    • Reflex inhibition via increased noradrenergic discharge in splanchnic nerves (especially from peritoneal irritation). (Option C)
    • Activation of opioid receptors further suppresses intestinal motility. (Option B)
  • Common Causes:
    • Surgical stress or trauma
    • Infection or inflammation: e.g., gastroenteritis, pancreatitis, peritonitis, diverticulitis
    • Electrolyte imbalances
    • Neurovascular impairment
    • Medications: particularly opioids and anticholinergics
  • Treatment Approach:
    • Symptom relief and addressing the underlying cause
    • Bowel rest with restricted oral intake
    • IV fluid therapy
    • Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) if prolonged
    • Nasogastric tube for decompression
    • Surgery if complications arise or conservative management fails

Key Takeaway:

  • Paralytic ileus results from impaired intestinal motility due to factors like surgical trauma, opioid use, or increased sympathetic discharge, all of which reduce peristalsis.

choices.text: The small intestine does not have plicae circulares

questions.text: Which of the following accurately distinguishes the small intestine from the large intestine?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Haustrations are pouch-like folds seen in the large intestine but are absent in the small intestine.

Key Takeaway:

  • Haustrations and tenia coli are distinctive features of the large intestine and are absent in the small intestine.
